statements.text: Acrisius, king of Argos, hears a prophecy that his grandson will one day cause his death and grows fearful of his daughter Danae.
Danae is shut in a bronze chamber, yet Zeus comes to her in the form of golden rain and she conceives a child.
When Perseus is born, Acrisius sets mother and child adrift on the sea in a wooden chest to escape the doom foretold by the oracle.
The chest washes ashore on Seriphos, where a fisherman finds Danae and brings her under the protection of the island’s ruler.
Polydectes plots to remove Perseus and tricks him into vowing to bring back the head of Medusa as a gift to the king.
Athena and Hermes appear as helpers to Perseus, giving him a polished shield and a keen sword suited to the dangerous journey.
By seizing the shared eye of the Graeae, Perseus forces the gray sisters to reveal the secret path to the nymphs who guard divine treasures.
From the nymphs, Perseus receives winged sandals and a cap of invisibility that will let him reach and escape the Gorgon’s lair.
Medusa is the only mortal Gorgon, a serpent-haired woman whose gaze turns those who meet her eyes into stone.
Guided by Athena’s counsel, Perseus approaches the sleeping Medusa and uses the bright shield as a mirror to avoid her deadly gaze while he strikes.
After the Gorgon is beheaded, Pegasus springs from the blood of Medusa in one renowned version of the tale.
Perseus carries the severed head of Medusa in a special bag, knowing that even in death her face can still petrify whoever looks upon it.
On a distant shore, Andromeda is chained to a rock as an offering to a ravaging sea monster sent to punish the pride of her parents.
Perseus uses the severed Gorgon head to turn the sea monster to stone and wins Andromeda as his bride according to the local king’s promise.
In later imaginings, Pegasus becomes the winged horse of poets, though in the Gorgon myth he first flies free after the death of Medusa.
Polydectes persecutes Danae and boasts that no mortal can return alive from facing Medusa, trusting that his schemes will never be punished.
When Perseus finally appears in the king’s hall, he reveals Medusa’s head and turns Polydectes and his companions to stone.
After the tyrant’s fall, Seriphos passes into gentler hands, and Hermes retrieves the winged sandals that had once been lent for the perilous quest.
At athletic games in a foreign land, Perseus throws a discus that veers into the crowd and accidentally kills Acrisius, fulfilling the old prophecy at last.
The slaying of Medusa and the trickery used against the Graeae become favorite subjects for ancient poets, who dwell on both the horror and the cunning of the adventure.
